Posts.EditableText: Hey - I am creating a text adventurer game but the "container" function for an object doesn't appear to be working. In the game, when a player opens a wardrobe, they find a key. However, when the wardrobe opens, nothing happens. No key appears. Any ideas?
Posts.HTML: Hey - I am creating a text adventurer game but the "container" function for an object doesn't appear to be working. In the game, when a player opens a wardrobe, they find a key. However, when the wardrobe opens, nothing happens. No key appears. Any ideas?

Posts.EditableText:
I’m not in front of my PC right now but try this first:
1.  Make sure you check the box that says something about listing objects when opened under the wardrobe object.
2.  Try looking at the key and the wardrobe after opening the wardrobe and see if it prints the automatic message (something like it contains a key).
3.  Make sure the key is visible.
4.  I’ve had issues with containers especially if I use one and change it to some other kind of container.  So maybe, delete the whole container and redo it.  That tends to be my coverall.

Let us know.
Posts.HTML:
I’m not in front of my PC right now but try this first:

  1. Make sure you check the box that says something about listing objects when opened under the wardrobe object.
  2. Try looking at the key and the wardrobe after opening the wardrobe and see if it prints the automatic message (something like it contains a key).
  3. Make sure the key is visible.
  4. I’ve had issues with containers especially if I use one and change it to some other kind of container. So maybe, delete the whole container and redo it. That tends to be my coverall.

Let us know.

Posts.EditableText: Also check the key is inside the wardrobe. Quest will try tp put it in the room by default.
Posts.HTML: Also check the key is inside the wardrobe. Quest will try tp put it in the room by default.

Posts.EditableText: Cheers both - managed to get it working (first attempt at a game as a present!)
Posts.HTML: Cheers both - managed to get it working (first attempt at a game as a present!)
